transcription.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
Thank you, everyone, for being here.
Could you raise your hand if you were in the rave last night?
Extra thanks for being here.
So I hope you had fun, and I hope we
can have fun in the next 50 minutes.
As the panel says, we are going to talk about who
are the next billion Ethereum users,
and how can Ethereum positively impact their lives.
I'm super privileged and honored to be here
with the new fellows from Ethereum Foundation,
Mihalo, Mari, Joffrey.
And we're going to be talking about the different projects,
the different motivations, why are there personally
moved to be addressing these next billion people they think
they are going to be impacted by Ethereum.
And why don't we start with a round of introductions.
Mari, do you want to first?
Sure.
My name is Mari P. Davies, and my project
is the Digital Asset Perpetuity Project.
And the goal of the project is to answer the question,
what happens to your ETH when you die?
Where are you coming from?
Tell us a little bit about your background, Mari.
I'm a legal technologist and a researcher.
I have a background in compliance and law,
and I did a master's thesis on basically digital assets
that were things like Facebook pages and that kind of thing.
And it led me to looking at digital assets
that have the value and how to transfer those when you die.
And yeah, that's basically how I got to where I'm at now.
So it sounds that you're the kind of people
that read the terms and conditions of everything, right?
I do.
I read terms and conditions.
Yeah, I do.
OK.
OK.
And what brought you to the web tree world?
What brought you to DevCon?
How do you connect where you were coming from to this world?
Well, when you start looking at the trouble people
have with digital assets, like a Facebook page or their email,
and then you think, OK, that's a problem.
But it's not something that they've invested tens of thousands
of dollars in that suddenly disappears when they die.
I mean, right now we have no process for transferring
our digital assets when we die.
And as the value goes up and the popularity goes up,
that's going to become a bigger and bigger problem.
It sounds like an opportunity there, yeah?
Thanks, Elmo.
Thank you.
Thank you, Mary.
Geoffrey, do you want to introduce yourself?
Sure.
Thanks.
Thanks so much.
So my name is Geoffrey.
I'm a co-founder at a Y Combinator Backstartup called
POCO.
And I think, for me, how I'm involved as a fellow
in the Ethereum Foundation is that I've
been looking a lot at how we can better get regulators to interact
with web tree technology and to learn and understand
not just the technology that we have here,
but also the culture that we have around decentralization
and how they can build better policies
that the intersection between decentralized
and centralized systems.
Interesting interest.
Actually, there was a very hot conversation
about regulations right now before the panel started.
Geoffrey, can you tell us a little bit about your background?
Are you an engineer?
Are you-- yeah?
Can you tell us a little bit more?
So I kind of took almost like accidental journey
into the regulation and policy making process.
I actually started out-- I got first introduced to Bitcoin
in 2012 when I was in MIT doing research.
And then I was working on the product and technology side
of things, launching a protocol in 2017.
And then I found myself having to work a lot more
with regulators since then.
Not the most fun thing to do, but very important.
And I was actually helping the central bank in Singapore
kind of launch their experiments around blockchain
technology so they can learn and understand
what's going on there.
But I think my journey and interest in blockchain technology
is a lot more personal.
So I used to run a nonprofit that
trained woman entrepreneurs in an all-fact sanctioned country.
We were doing everything compliantly.
And then one day the bank comes to us and they said, hey,
you are operating a high risk environment.
We are going to shut down your company's--
your nonprofits bank account.
And that was a huge blow to us.
It took a lot of time to sort out those issues.
And the worst part of it is that we didn't do anything wrong.
We were compliant.
The bank made a business decision around the risk
they had to face.
And I see that problem happening again today
where because of the perception of regulators
and the pressure from regulators,
they are conflating activities that are legitimate and illegitimate.
And I think vastly affecting the industry.
I think that's something that motivates me
to help regulators better understand what web trees are all about.
Awesome, Geoffrey.
So as Mary was introducing herself and now Geoffrey,
we can see that probably because we don't like to talk about that
and because we don't like to talk with regulators,
maybe we can find the next billion people there, right?
So I'm here.
Look, can you share a bit about your motivations,
your background?
Thank you, Chey.
Hello, everyone.
My name is Michailo.
I'm coming from the World Organization of the Scald Movement.
This is where I lead the digital transformation
and technological projects.
So can I say highlights?
Yeah, like this.
Like this?
OK.
Yeah.
So I'm the scout in the room.
So, yeah, I'm here with the Terry and Fellowship.
And my project is basically about looking
into how to gear up the movement,
educational, non-formal educational movement,
like scouting is, of 58 million members in 220 territories
around the world.
How do we bring them and get them ready for a Web 3.0?
How do we work with young people
and to understand the blockchain and to be the citizens
of the future world?
Yeah.
And what about your educational background?
Where are you coming from, in that sense?
Sure.
My education background is project management.
Then I basically, all the time, I
was in the IT type of projects and technological projects.
I volunteered for the scouting for most of my life.
I was a scout and volunteered and then started very early,
actually, to work for the world organization, the scout
movement, first in the European level,
and then later on now at the global headquarters, which
is now based in Malaysia for the past nine years.
Awesome.
Awesome.
Love it.
So we can tell that, perhaps, from--
and I will try to over simplify, so no means to this respect.
So for my volunteering kind of approach,
from a legal tech approach and for my policymaking approach,
let's see and let's dig deeper into what's the next billion.
What we are thinking will be the next billion users
for the entire community.
Geoffrey, when you think or when you hear this question,
or when you join the next billion team,
I send out their own fellow, what's
the persona that comes to your mind?
Can you describe that person or that stereotype or that subject?
Yeah.
So we are doing a lot of work with the government
of Kazakhstan to pilot certain experiments
around web tree technology and also web tree regulations.
And I think the one thing that really stood out to me
was that the central bank did a survey,
and they found that 25% of the population
had exposure to crypto.
And I think you'll see that consistent number going anywhere
from 10% to 30% in most countries around the world.
And I think when you think about it,
there's really a population of 70% that would not
have touched any of these technologies,
almost in every country in the world.
So I see it as a very, very big pool of people
who have not had access to crypto, have not touched it.
And then once you think about actual decentralized technology,
because most people's their first exposure is true on-rams,
true centralized exchanges, once you think about actually,
say, hey, have you set up a math mask?
Have you used any DAP?
That number drops to maybe 5% 3%.
And I think that's really the gap that we're
trying to close in a number of ways.
Interesting.
I love when this is statistics come,
and they say, hey, just in 2021, the crypto adoption
went like a 2,000%-- like, oh, that's a lot.
But just in Latin America, it's like 30 million people
out of 650 million.
So it represents almost nothing.
There is a billion hidden there, right?
Marie, what about you?
What's the persona that you think
or that comes to your mind when you think of the next billion?
Well, when I think of the next billion,
I don't think of it from the perspective of a persona.
I think of it more as a product.
And then I think, what exactly are we selling to the next billion?
And if I drill down into it, what I see is what we're selling
is a trusted product and service.
And if we take a step down from that, what we're selling
is trust.
So what we need to do to reach the next billion
is to build the trust of our ecosystem
and the products and services that we make.
Because if people don't trust us, they won't use us.
OK, so interesting.
I'm willing to dig deeper here, but I don't know how to put it.
I'll come back.
I'll come back to that.
It will come to me.
Can you describe the scales?
I believe that the scales are your personas, right?
Yeah, that's actually what I have in mind.
I have in mind not just scales, but young people.
The future is in them.
And we talk about building trust with the regulators.
We talk about these challenges.
But the future regulators will be the young people of today.
And those people are not falling into these technologies
and things.
For them, this is all more natural, more open.
They're more open-minded.
There's less foreign for them.
But what we need to do to reach that one next billion,
I think we need to work with the young people,
thinking of the long-term future, work in the presence.
Work now with the regulators, work with the oldest stakeholders
right now and the people in the room.
But also think of the future and work
with the young generations.
That will be the future regulators, future users, future--
and mobilizing, mobilizing more showing to the world
that blockchain is not only about crypto,
that is about doing good, that is technology for good,
and showing them what I felt here when I came first day,
that this is really about everybody
is in the mission of doing something good
and solving some real-life problems.
So if we could build the trust by showing to everyone
becoming from a niche group, as you
said, that growth becoming a mainstream, the parties
to really build the trust and make ourselves more open.
And I believe that the web tree and blockchain ecosystem
in general has a lot to learn about these scouts.
These scouts kind of organically or naturally
organize in different nodes, right?
It's a very interesting approach to see things.
So I became an Ethereum fellow during hard years.
This is the first time I met the next billion team
in person.
But even though we didn't have the time to share in person,
the term foundation helped me a lot.
Because I work with public institutions,
because I want to teach public servants and also
serve technology and also bring them into web tree technologies
and kind of get into your government portal.
And instead of creating a digital profile,
just connect your wallet.
So that kind of approach for us was, let's jump into the web tree
and let's bring institutions into the web tree.
That was my approach to applying into a term foundation
and to become a fellow and to try to learn
how the term foundation can help us
and how we can also help the Ethereum ecosystem.
When you think of that, when you think of how you applied
to become an Ethereum fellow, what's the problem you were
describing with this person?
What's that thing that personally moves you to be tackling
or addressing or trying to gather these next billion people?
Joffrey, do you want to go on?
Yeah, sure.
I think the big gap with working regulators is that they--
and policymakers is that they don't--
going back to the problem statement I had
was that they don't understand the culture.
They don't understand the technology.
You ask a regulator, have they used a manor mask?
None of them would have done it.
I just want to check-- in the audience,
is there any regulators or policymakers in this audience
here?
Raise your hand if anyone?
OK.
So I think that's--
We clearly need to go for them, right?
Yeah.
You can't understand the culture without being here,
without feeling it and interacting with the community.
And the approach that we are taking
is to get regulators to experiment with the technology.
So in Kazakhstan, for example, we
are working with the government on two different projects.
One is around provision of public services.
So they have a national IT park.
They have a bunch of education activities around it.
And they say, hey, if we transform this
into a decentralized autonomous organization,
what does it look?
How will people use the technology?
Will people need to-- how do they open up wallets?
How do they use those wallets to interact with each other?
These are things they're all very, very new to most people
in the world.
And they want to experiment and try
and see to understand exactly what it is
that they're dealing with here.
The other thing is that they're introducing a national crypto
fiat reel by mandate.
But then as they start doing it, they say, oh,
we have all the stakeholders with all these different issues.
How do we think about it?
What's happening out there?
And I think learning by doing is just
so critical in trying to understand the web tree
space from a policy makeup perspective.
Interesting.
Interesting.
In your case, Marie, is there any personal motivation
that you feel that it's moving you
to tackle the problem that you're referring?
I love how you introduce yourself.
And I say, hey, I'm Marie.
I'm working on how to-- what will happen to you,
eat when you die?
So it's really good.
But is there anything that is actually moving you towards there?
Is there anything you want to share on how you apply
to Ethereum Foundation?
How you describe this problem?
And what moves you to be pulling these next billion people
towards the ecosystem?
Well, I think that without getting all deathy,
when people die, transferring assets
from the individual to their estate
is extremely complicated.
It involves not only inheritance laws, state law,
but contract law, privacy law.
And it isn't as simple as just handing over the asset.
And the laws are very old.
And they're complicated.
And different jurisdictions have different laws.
And in some jurisdictions, multiple laws apply.
And I thought that the way to approach
the problem of what happens to you when you die
is to, at first, build a database of all
of the laws that apply across the world
to transfer of assets on death.
And then to look for patterns in those laws.
And then to sort of compile that as a list of requirements
and then approach the community and say,
these are the legal problems that we have with assets
transfer on death.
How do we use our technology to solve them?
And that was the sort of driver that got me going
and realizing that if we disrupt--
I call disrupt from within.
If we look at how it works now and look at what needs
to be reformed and changed and how technology can replace
things like wills need a wedding signature.
That's crazy.
They need to be on paper.
That's crazy.
I mean, we have technology that can do that
without either of those requirements.
But unless we understand the law enough
to know that that solution will work,
I think we risk flying in the face of disruption
and being opposed by the powers that regulate that sort
of thing rather than being accepted by them.
Interesting.
And it's-- you just made me think that when we die,
when we have money in a regular bank like Fiat,
like for example in Mexico, if you have no will
and no one claims it, the bank just used to use money.
Yeah.
That's the way it goes.
But here, when we're thinking about it, for example,
it's bad for you and it's bad for the ecosystem
because the heat got locked.
So the problem gets bigger and bigger, right?
And that's a problem for an individual.
It's also a problem for our ecosystem.
If digital assets are frozen or--
I mean, think of a service provider
that has frozen ethonist books, how do they handle that?
I don't know.
So yeah, it is-- and also going back to my trust point,
if we can't be transfer assets the way other assets transferred,
are people going to trust ETH itself
or digital assets registered on blockchain with smart contracts?
So it's a multiple layer problem.
Very interesting.
Yeah, very interesting problem.
So going to Yumi Halo, are you thinking of an actual problem
or an opportunity that is personally
moving you to kind of persuade these 58 million people, you said?
Yeah, 58 million people.
To come in-- so what are you thinking?
What are your thoughts behind that?
So as a scouting-- as a scout, myself, and scouting,
is in a mission of creating better world.
We do that by creating better citizens for the future.
We do that by providing them non-formal education opportunities.
So bringing these other education that nobody talked about so much
or is not-- but is actually bigger.
And in some cases, also more relevant,
especially in today's times where education is evolving.
So education, education, education.
So it's really really about that.
So personally, I am on that mission,
looking into how we educate more young people to use this,
how we get more and more users, and how we-- with that spark,
their curiosity.
And there is not that we are giving-- and this
is how you do it, so we go and be doer.
But hey, this is how you do it.
But you can think of other solutions and other way
to build something on this and feel free.
And how do we nurture that community within community?
So my goal would be to create one of the things
that we do in the project is to create a community
within scouting that works on the blockchains,
the scouts who are interested about victory--
victory zero and blockchain and support their work,
basically not direct them, not guide them,
but just support their initiatives.
And I'm thinking to do that like a dull community as well,
also within the scouting.
So I believe that's the answer for this, I think.
Very interesting.
I can think about multiple things from digital identity.
And I remember Daniel Ryan sharing on the opening
that probably the next steps for the thermo ecosystem
are not going to be financial, but perhaps tapping
into the potential of identities.
And I can see an opportunity here and there's--
yep.
Just one thought about the depth that you mentioned.
And that is you reminded me of a very important
problem that we look into solving.
It's a big challenge of today, of course,
is the child abuse, abuse of any kind, not a child,
but anyone, adult, young people, any abuse, any form of abuse.
I am very interested to figure out
how technology can help us in that.
And I believe there is a way it can help us.
It's about, yeah, partially on education,
but partially also about figuring out
the system and mechanisms for creating
a safe environment for everyone.
I think that's also something I'm very like motivated
and driven to.
So that will be one of the important initiatives
that I'm scouting.
Very interesting.
And I can see the hard part of the motivation behind.
So that's what we need to get the next billion
to be like purpose-driven and persist.
And that's going to be it.
So before I jump into opening questions
and opening the floor for the audience
to tap into different things around what you have been sharing,
I would love you to share where are you going?
Or how do you think the thermo ecosystem
can help you to reach these next billion?
Do you have any challenges in mind?
Where do you see yourself in six months from now
into reaching these next billion?
Jeffrey, you want to go?
Yeah, so I think one of the issues where
I see this decentralized system meeting centralized system
kind of bumping up against quite frequently,
I think it's in the crypto fiat rails.
And I do believe that that's due very much
to call through which most new users in the world
will start to get access to this ecosystem.
And I think it's something that there
needs to be ways to kind of facilitate that
and make that a more seamless transition.
And in many parts of the world, it's
getting a lot more restrictive.
I go to my bank and I say, my company
is dealing a lot with crypto.
The bank, when you say, oh, high risk customer, forget it.
I'm going to shut down your bank account.
So I think that's one area.
I love to talk to people.
If they have to deal with these issues,
especially from kind of compliance,
I love to engage with people to learn
about the conversations they're having in a confidential manner.
And what can best be done to persuade regulators
that there isn't the kind of risk that they imagine
exists in this ecosystem?
The other part I'm super excited about actually is gaming.
I'm a gamer.
And I believe that actually in Southeast Asia,
where I live, I'm currently in Vietnam,
I think games is a very, very great way
to introduce a lot of people that don't have experience
kind of with this ecosystem and get them into it.
Even the doubt that we are working
in the National IT Park in Kazakhstan,
actually came out from an original thinking
where they are trying to say, how do I
gamify the experience and involvement of my community
with the infrastructure that we have?
And now it's extended into the WAP tree space.
So I think that's another area that I'm just super excited about.
And I love to talk to people who know the WAP tree gaming
space better than I do.
Awesome.
Awesome.
Mary, where do you see or what's the obstacle?
What's the challenges that we are seeing up front
in the next six months for your project
and for reaching this next billion?
Well, I think in six months, we'll
have a database of all the law that
applies to the transfer of digital assets when you die.
And I want it to be an open source database.
So I'm going to need some sort of a platform to record it
and make it accessible to people.
And then the next step is to create
the list of legal requirements for what
needs to happen in different jurisdictions.
And then what I'm hoping is that the community
will be able to look at those and say, OK,
we've got the technology to do this and this.
We can solve this problem with a technical solution.
And that's the vision for the next phase of my project.
OK, interesting.
What about you, Mihilo?
Do you see any challenges there?
I mean, I can picture some of them.
But what do you see your next steps for the audience?
Can you share with the audience?
You're going--
Sure.
Thanks, Rui.
So we'll start with the smaller bytes, of course,
and the things that would be easy and will actually
be something that's caused would be very motivated and easy
going to accept is that we will, of course,
start creating or putting the scout badges into the--
turning them into the NFT badges and putting them
in via Pope and other technologies
will put them into the wallet.
So we'll have a scout wallet with scout badges.
So that will help bring on scouts on a basics
on a first level understanding, having--
what's the hash, what's the private key, what's the NFT,
what's the wallet.
And then we go into deeper.
We go into, again, having these champions
in inside of the community, looking
into what projects we could get into,
what projects we could do, what are the worst relevant ones.
I heard so many good ideas since I came here
about what we can do in scouting, for example.
You mentioned we are decentralized.
Yes, we have local scout groups everywhere in this neighborhood.
Also, there is a scout group, actually.
And they need some support in creating
a simple treasury mechanism where a blockchain,
or they also, like, scouting is voluntary led,
meaning that people are voted for and elected to lead
and then to represent them in the other circles,
so using DAO there and things like that.
So what I'm looking forward from these communities,
like ideas and openness, maybe to suggest some things
and help us actually do these things.
We are nonprofit, and we're looking
forward for anyone who we want to partner on a doing good basis
and do something great together to solve some big problems.
Awesome.
I remember when I was a kid, it was a used to be a scout.
And I remember having different pins
because of the different accomplishments or milestones.
So now we are going to have pull-ups, maybe, right?
Exactly.
So there's 25 more minutes here,
and I believe that this is a good amount of time
for opening to the floor.
Anyone in the audience wants to pick the brains
of these fellows and how they are planning
to reach the next billion users.
One seg-bidding.
Hello. Great to meet you all.
Fantastic work you're doing.
One of the things I heard is the use cases
that you are all approaching or existing use cases.
Payments, smart contracts, maybe DIY or credentialing,
at least for scouts.
And so what it sounds like is we've done well
for these first billion with this use case.
Let's push that to another billion.
Jeffrey, you mentioned gaming.
Are there other use cases that you see
as you look at different sort of populations?
Or is it a matter of we've got some good use cases,
we just need to reach more people.
I'm just curious about your thoughts
on a macro level on that stuff.
So I think the-- so for me, the way I look at this
is that when I think of the next billion,
it's that I think different countries
interact and learn about crypto in very different ways.
So going back to the Kazakhstan example,
it was quite interesting.
What happened in Kazakhstan was that China banned mining
and all the miners fled to Kazakhstan.
And then they were like, at first, they panicked
because they consume a lot of electricity.
Kazakhstan, I think, went quite a number one,
a number two hash rate in the world.
And the government panicked and they overreacted
and they kind of clamped down on it.
And then after that, they said, hey,
this is actually a very interesting industry.
We need to do more about it, more in it.
And then they started inviting exchanges back
into Kazakhstan, you know, binance set up there,
a bunch of other exchanges went in there
and got established.
So I think it's-- the way I look at it is to do that,
we need new applications that provide benefit to people
on a day-to-day basis.
But I think that the pool of people that we have not touched
is still very, very huge.
Because you go in there and they are
at the beginning of learning about this.
Most of them would still not have a mass wallet.
25% of the population owns digital assets.
But there is a lens and a process in which some of these
countries learn about crypto.
And I think it's still a very, very early stage
in terms of the 75% or 80% of each of these countries
that crypto has not touched it.
So to build on that and about the use cases--
and this is more happening to my experience
from the previous year being an Ethereum fellow--
working with the public sector, typically,
there's no one wanting to be the pioneer, pioneer.
They want to be the second pioneer, the third pioneer,
but not the first one, right?
So winning these small battles, having these different use
cases, is always super relevant.
This is kind of a divide-and-conquer approach.
It's more on the mindset of them.
We started, for example, with just verifiable credentials
for commercial permits.
That was a very simple thing.
And then at some point, we started
certifying city inspectors and policemen
so that you were able to actually scan and see
if that was an actual policeman and doing their job.
And then we started into construction permits.
And then we are now thinking about legislation.
There's actually a congresswoman here doing that thing.
She's in her WhatsApp right now.
But she's helping with the legislation right now,
but because of the use cases.
So after we moved with around 50 different implementations,
different flavors just at the ones I just mentioned,
we were able to start thinking about low initiatives.
And after low initiatives, you can start thinking about how
regulation can foster innovation, not block innovation.
And then after that, we start stitching the ecosystem
and saying, hey, can we have standards?
Can we share the same thing when we talk about identity
or public sector credentials or a sense of ownership
of your digital assets?
And then we are now integrating even with more web tree services.
So everything departed from the use cases.
And this was just to highlight the relevance of your request.
So thank you, Yafri.
Do you want to add on that?
I actually just want to add a quick point.
I think because you raised something very interesting
in terms of how regulators think about this technology.
I think one of the biggest fears is that there
is different use cases for web tree in different countries.
If I'm a small country, I might think differently.
If I'm a big country, I want to regulate in a different way
because I have different interests at stake.
And what I see in this space is because most of them
do not understand the technology and don't
have access to the expertise, they will just copy the US
most of the time.
And the US chooses to regulate web tree in a way
because they have particular policy interests that
doesn't-- isn't the same chat interest
as all those different countries.
So definitely, there is this novel effect here.
The more problems you find, the more business
and impact opportunities you find as well.
So any other question?
Anyone wants to jump in?
Do you want to help?
Hi.
So I was thinking, is there any way
that the Ethereum Foundation is documenting
this kind of growth, building blocks,
and how every single one of you have a different approach
on how we can reach that next billion?
So is there any kind of documentation
on how the growth, building blocks are starting to merge
with the patterns that you're discovering?
Do you have any plans for sharing any of the kind
of the documentation that you have any plans to--
[INAUDIBLE]
No, it's a good question.
I mean, we have plans to look into--
understand a little bit what's the stage zero, where we are
at the moment, and then to measure
throughout the time of these projects, what's the impact made,
and what has changed from the zero.
So for example, for my project, I
will be looking into where we are and scouting.
I'll be identifying some use cases.
